description: A practical pricing-model pack: common pricing architectures, when to use them, how to test them, and guardrails for unit economics and ethics. Built for business decision-making and offer design.
corePrinciples: Pricing is a strategy lever, not a math exercise.
Value-based pricing dominates cost-plus when differentiation exists.
A pricing model is a constraint system: it shapes behavior, churn, and support load.
Unit economics must work at the margin (contribution margin > 0 at target CAC).
Good pricing is legible: customers understand what they pay and why.
Segmentation is the engine: different willingness-to-pay deserves different offers.
Always test: price sensitivity is discovered, not assumed.

pricingModelCatalog.notes: Use when ongoing marginal cost is low or explicitly carved out via maintenance/support add-ons.
Keep tiers few and crisp. Define renewal value clearly.
Differentiate tiers by outcomes/limits, not a long list of tiny features.
Add caps, alerts, and a predictable middle tier to reduce anxiety.
Consider active-user pricing or role-based seats to prevent gaming.
Define measurement rules up front. Prefer hybrid (base + success) for stability.
Gate by limits that correlate with value: usage caps, collaboration, automation, or premium outcomes.
Time-box, define success criteria, and require activation steps. Trials without activation are fake signals.
Bundle around a job-to-be-done, not a random pile of features.
Treat as a campaign with an end date. Communicate future list price early.
Requires strong positioning and credible proof.

guidelines: Segment by value and constraints, not demographics.
Use tiers to map segments to clear outcomes.
Keep one tier that is an obvious default.

valueMetric: Define the unit that correlates with delivered value (seat, usage, outcome, project).
Ensure the value metric is measurable, understandable, and hard to game.
Align value metric with cost drivers when possible.
packagingRules: Differentiate on outcomes, limits, access, and risk reduction.
Avoid gating core success behind too many paywalls.
discountingRules: Discounts are a lever; apply with intent and a deadline.
Prefer giving more value over lowering price (bonus, bundle, extended support).
Never discount without tracking effect on conversion and churn.

methods.notes: Use consistent questions to avoid biasing responses.

principles: Avoid deceptive pricing (hidden fees, surprise renewals).
Make terms legible: cancellation, renewal, limits, overages.
Be careful with vulnerable populations and high-pressure sales tactics.

decisionHeuristics: If value scales with usage and costs scale with usage, consider usage-based pricing.
If adoption is team-based and collaboration is core, consider seat-based pricing.
If outcomes are measurable and trusted, consider hybrid outcome pricing.
If there are multiple segments, use tiered subscription and clear upgrade triggers.
If buyer risk is high, use a trial/pilot with explicit success criteria.
diagnosticQuestions: What value metric best represents delivered value?
Which segment is the default tier designed for?
What is the main churn driver and how does pricing interact with it?
Where can customers get surprised (fees, renewals, overages)?
Does discounting improve retention or just win low-quality customers?
